Hey guys, I‚Äôve been an on-and-off-again user of Signal. I first started using Signal just before the pandemic and at that time I felt like the shortcomings of the app were too great for me to make this my main communication app despite the privacy and security features.

Today I heard some great news about the data backup/portability feature. This should have been developed years ago as I switch back and forth between an iPhone and a Google Pixel. Is the 45-day limit only for attachments at the free tier or will messages backed up will have a longer timeframe? If I subscribe, will the 45-day limitation be removed? If there is demand, can more storage tiers be made available, say for a ‚Äúbusiness‚Äù account?

As someone who uses an iPhone, Pixel, MacBook Air, and an iPad, will the upcoming update or in the future allow me to use 4 devices simultaneously? If so, how will Signal handle message synchronization? I feel like even in 2025, no one has really nailed this 100% of the time. iMessage and even WhatsApp feel inconsistent and unreliable with message history and that‚Äôs a centralized system. Will or can Signal get better at this?

In light of the increased scrutiny at the US border, I‚Äôm wondering if Signal is planning to make a web client? Non-citizens don‚Äôt have a right to enter the US and if CBP asked for access to a phone and I declined, then I risk being denied entry and deported. Signal‚Äôs decentralized nature seems to have some disadvantages. If I delete Signal from my phone before I clear immigration, then that prevents anyone from reading them, but what do I do if I want to retrieve it after clearing immigration? Looking for advice on this matter. If nothing exists, will Signal develop something to address this problem when entering and leaving the US?

posts.cooked:
iluvsignal1:

This should have been developed years ago

They started planning in ~2019/2020 and have been building it ever since.

iluvsignal1:

Is the 45-day limit only for attachments at the free tier or will messages backed up will have a longer timeframe?

45 days applies to the free tier. See this post for more detail.

iluvsignal1:

If I subscribe, will the 45-day limitation be removed?

Yes. See this topic.

iluvsignal1:

If there is demand, can more storage tiers be made available, say for a ‚Äúbusiness‚Äù account?

If they want to keep it affordable and the maintenance of the service simple, there probably won‚Äôt be more options anytime soon.

iluvsignal1:

As someone who uses an iPhone, Pixel, MacBook Air, and an iPad, will the upcoming update or in the future allow me to use 4 devices simultaneously?

With this mixture of devices, you can already do this with everything but the iPhone/Pixel. Only one phone can be the primary device.

iluvsignal1:

If so, how will Signal handle message synchronization?

Primary device is the smartphone that registered the phone number. Link computers and iPads (Android tablets not supported) up to 5 devices.

iluvsignal1:

I‚Äôm wondering if Signal is planning to make a web client?

There used to be a chrome web app, but that was deprecated in favor of the current desktop app. For security reasons, they‚Äôll probably never have a web app again.

iluvsignal1:

Signal‚Äôs decentralized nature seems to have some disadvantages.

Signal is not decentralized, but decentralization has several disadvantages.

iluvsignal1:

but what do I do if I want to retrieve it after clearing immigration?

Android currently has a local backup option. In the future there will be cloud backup, and a universal local backup option that will let you create and restore backups across platforms. Uninstalling Signal and restoring from a cloud backup after passing immigration would be the simplest option.

posts.name: Delamcode
posts.cooked:
Yes, as long as each device is connected and synced every 45 days (your primary device will notify you if any device is close to that limit), any offline devices will first fetch all messages that haven‚Äôt already been fetched (45 days of messages are stored on Signal‚Äôs servers) and then you can use any linked device basically as you would your primary. Keep in mind, that if a device hasn‚Äôt been synced recently and you send/receive many attachments, I‚Äôve noticed it may sometimes take a minute or two for the syncing step. (Molly helps here, as your primary can be your Pixel iPhone and your iPhone Pixel your secondary. Your primary does not need to be online to receive messages on linked devices)

Edit: Molly allows the Android to be a linked device and the iPhone will be primary as is default, not the other way around

I did read that post. You seem to think that it‚Äôs 45 days for everything. I‚Äôm reading as all text messages including the ones older than 45 days are backed up. It‚Äôs just the media that have a 45-day limit, but no limit with a subscription.

Is the current implementation very good at keeping my messages in synchronization when using multiple devices or that some messages appear out of order?

With the new update, can I link two phones to the account with one being the primary?

How will the cloud backup work? Is there a best practice on how to use Signal when entering the US?

You mean with Molly or what? With just Signal, do you use multiple devices and are all messages in sync and in order? I feel like neither iMessage nor WhatsApp is reliable either.

Are the messages stored in the cloud if the primary device is offline?

posts.name: Delamcode
posts.cooked:
There‚Äôs two different features in Signal. Syncing and Backups are two different features. Syncing only syncs 45 days of messages, as that much is stored on the servers. The new Universal Backups (which are not yet released - currently it‚Äôs in staging, so expect to possibly wait a few months) will allow local or cloud backups between devices. This means, that if you currently had only an iPhone, with this feature, you could switch to a brand new Pixel with all your data restored. If all you need is to have all your messages on all devices at all times, and assuming you set up all your linked devices at the start of using Signal, you can use the Sync feature (technically sync is only syncing 45 days of messages when linking a new device, but we can assume it‚Äôs the same for the sake of simplicity), which is already out and free, you only need to open Signal on all devices at least once every 45 days (meaning the 45 day timer restarts when the app is last closed on the device).
Sorry if my message is a little confusing lol

posts.name: Delamcode
posts.cooked: Messages are always stored in the cloud for 45 days (encrypted ofc). Earlier I misspoke, I meant using the iPhone as primary and your Pixel as a linked device. iPads, Desktops, etc are always linked devices (ofc this is possible to change with 3rd party clients, but I think it‚Äôs more unreliable). This would mean your iPhone would have control over your other devices (Pixel, Desktop‚Ä¶), and the only 3rd-party client that would need to be installed is on the Pixel. The iPhone can be primary as intended, and desktop can be linked as intended. It was just, at least for now, not intended for a Pixel to be used as a linked device, but is possible with something like Molly

Ok, I think I understand. So as long as one of my devices is online, I‚Äôll never have to worry about the 45-day limit. Right?

What about messages in order? I don‚Äôt chat a lot, but over the years, I have never found a service that works perfectly with multiple devices. There have always been some messages out of order.

posts.name: Delamcode
posts.cooked:
Each device must be online every 45 days. It may be possible to restore from a backup if you only do it on one device, but I haven‚Äôt personally tried it, as the feature isn‚Äôt even available in staging for my devices yet.
I‚Äôve never found such issues (on official Apps) about timing. I have however had messages have weird datestamps when texting someone else, but this was usually because one of our time settings was wrong by a minute or two. Messages were still shown to me in the right order when this happened however.

I feel like I‚Äôm missing something since you keep emphasizing 45 days. So let‚Äôs say my iPhone is primary and linked to my desktop. I started using today for the next two weeks. After that, I linked an iPad. Will the iPad be able to get the messages from the first two weeks? I would think yes? What if I add a Pixel with Molly on the same day as the iPad?

Maybe I‚Äôm the only one who really cares, but message order is very important to me. Has this been rigorously tested?

posts.name: Delamcode
posts.cooked:
When linking a new device, the past 45 days of messages will be synced (if the option that shows up is chosen), and since 14<45, that would be all your messages in your example. If you would like earlier messages, it will possible to use a backup from your primary in the future. All devices will get new messages, if you open them and least every 45 days. The reason for this, is that the server stores messages for 45 days. After this time, only your devices (which have been opened recently) still have the messages, and as such, a backup will have to be made if you would like to transfer older messages.

I can only tell you from my experience that I‚Äôve never had an issue with message order in official Apps. I am not a developer, so I cannot tell you what rigorous testing they may or may not have done. If anyone else has had issues with this, feel free to chime in.

You‚Äôre so helpful! Thank you!

I think you meant to say older messages? So let‚Äôs say that instead of adding my desktop on day 14, but on day 60, then I can‚Äôt sync all of the old messages, right? Now I‚Äôll have to make a backup from my primary device and then do a cloud restore on the desktop to have all the messages?

Can I do all of this now? It seems like you say yes, but I‚Äôm sort of reading that‚Äôs being tested now? How will things get better in the future besides the ability to go back and forth between iPhones and Androids?

posts.name: Delamcode
posts.cooked:
I previously said cloud and universal local backups are in staging (testing) and will be possible in the future.
You are correct, so currently only the 45 day sync exists. If you have 60 days of messages and try to link a new device, it will only allow you (prompt you) to transfer 45 days of messages. Cloud backup and universal local backup will be available when this feature is released. I assume that it will allow you to restore the backup on linked devices, as it does for new primary devices.

Ok, I‚Äôm sorry. I did say I am a Signal newbie. I think I understand now.

I‚Äôll give Signal another try then. Hopefully, it‚Äôll actually work out this time!

I didn‚Äôt realize some of these features take this long to develop as I feel like it should have been there from the start.

I‚Äôm still curious. Do you or anyone know if Signal will have other private ways to sign up or the phone number will be the only method for the foreseeable future?

Has there been any discussion about developing an Apple Watch client? Currently, I‚Äôm forced to use FaceTime Audio. While I trust it, I still fear big tech and want to use Signal as much as I can.

What‚Äôs the max number of people in a video call?

Can we have multiple parties in an audio-only call like a conference call? If so, how many people?

Can Signal replace Google Meet or WhatsApp? I wonder what MS Teams and those other services have that Signal still doesn‚Äôt have?

Does anyone know if Signal works in authoritarian countries like China? How do I use Signal in China?

posts.name: Chloe
posts.cooked: @Delamcode @iluvsignal1 The entire message history is synced with the link+sync feature. The only limitation is media messages, where only the media will be unavailable for newly linked devices after 45 days (because then it‚Äôs no longer on the server).

posts.name: Chloe
posts.cooked:
iluvsignal1:

So I guess for people in my situation, is my privacy and security already compromised by signing up for Signal? Won‚Äôt my phone carrier, and I guess the government, know that I have signed up for Signal?

No, messages are more secure and private on Signal, because there is no metadata Signal can hand over that says who you were messaging or who was messaging you.
The government & your carrier may find out that you have registered for Signal because of the phone number requirement, depending on your country. In the US, fwiw, Signal includes their name in the registration code message. I have heard that in other countries this is not the case.
